title: Shared Care Tax Credit Statistics

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Shared Care Tax Credit Statistics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Information related to the Shared Care Tax Credit from as far back as data systems will allow through 2025. Specifically, the following information, as it is available:

1) Number of returns that claimed the credit
2) Total amount of credits claimed ($)
3) If available, (1) and (2) separately by taxpayer characteristics, such as filing status, marital status, age of taxpayer, AGI range, number of dependents, etc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Cecil County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Cecil County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

Here is what our RMS has for Use of Force synopsis.   Last column has a glitch.  If actual use of force reports are needed, we will have to go through legal and then determine an estimated cost as years of reports will have to be pulled and reviewed.

communications.subject: Formal Acknowledgement | Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the Georgia Department of Revenue. Please allow this to serve as the Department's initial response to and formal acknowledgement of your open records request.

The Department will attempt to provide all requested records, but due to confidentiality law, it is possible that some items may not be disclosed. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq., the Department will provide our formal response within 10 business days.

Under Georgia law, an agency may impose a reasonable charge for the search, redaction, and production or copying cost of records responsive to an Open Records Request. The time and cost will be calculated by using the hourly salary of the lowest paid employee qualified to conduct the research of an Open Records Request, with no charge for the first fifteen minutes of employee time expended. DOR will provide an estimate to the requestor if the reasonably anticipated costs for Production Tasks exceed $25 and will defer the Production Tasks until the requestor agrees to pay estimated costs.

Public Information Office
Georgia Department of Revenue
2595 Century Parkway, NE | Atlanta, GA 30345
Email: ORR@dor.ga.gov<mailto:ORR@dor.ga.gov>
Phone: 678-536-9348
dor.georgia.gov

communications.subject: GADOR Formal Response | Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
Below is a table addressing the first and second questions posed in your open records request.  The Department of Revenue does not track filing status, AGI, number of dependents or other taxpayer characteristics pertaining to taxpayers that claimed this credit.  O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(j) (“No public officer or agency shall be required to prepare new reports, summaries, or compilations not in existence at the time of the request.”).  In some cases, taxpayers may not have had a large enough liability to fully utilize the credits generated.  Hence, the claimed amount is less than the generated amount.  Data for 2025 is not yet available.

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
Thank you very much for your help with my request. I have one follow-up question- what is the difference between "Credit Generated" and "Credit Claimed on Returns"?

Thanks,
Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: Follow Up | Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
Ms. Pepin,

Generally speaking, the difference is as follows:


  *   Credit Generated: Total amount of credit a taxpayer is eligible for during a specific period.
  *   Credit Claimed: Credit amount a taxpayer applies against their tax liability.
     *   A taxpayer may not be able to claim the full amount generated if their tax liability is lower than the credit amount, or if there is a statutory cap on credits.

I’ve attached the tax credit summary document posted to DOR’s website to the extent it’s helpful to you.

Public Information Office
Georgia Department of Revenue
2595 Century Parkway, NE | Atlanta, GA 30345
Email: ORR@dor.ga.gov<mailto:ORR@dor.ga.gov>
dor.georgia.gov

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with Maurice Bransfield.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Cease and desist letters sent to Kalshi, Polymarket, and Crypto.com
communications.communication:
Mr. Hoover:

I have to deny your public records request as you have not presented proof of Tennessee citizenship.  Under the Tennessee Public Records Act, only citizens of Tennessee have the right to inspect and receive copies of public records. “All state, county and municipal records shall, at all times during business hours … be open for personal inspection by any citizen of this state, and those in charge of the records shall not refuse such right of inspection to any citizen, unless otherwise provided by state law.”  Tenn. Code Ann. § 10-7-503(a)(2)(A). Additionally, Sports Wagering Council (“SWC”) Rule 1350-04-.04(7) provides: “Proof of Tennessee citizenship, by presentation of a valid Tennessee driver’s license (or alternative acceptable form of ID as determined by the PRRC), is required as a condition to inspect or receive copies of public records and must be presented with the request.”



Thank you

Public Records Request Coordinator
Tennessee Sports Wagering Council
312 Rosa L Parks Ave., 8th Floor
Nashville, TN 37243

on 1/8/2026).


This email serves as notification that due to the current volume of
requests and limited University resources, EMU is extending the response
due date by ten (10) business days, as allowed by MCL15.235 of the Act
(attached) and will respond by 1/29/2026.


For further information on EMU's Procedures & Guidelines regarding FOIA,
please visit our website at
https://www.emich.edu/legal-affairs/foia/index.php

Best,
*Jordan D. Miller* | Assistant General Counsel
*Eastern Michigan University*
Legal Affairs
11 Welch Hall | Ypsilanti, MI 48197
Direct:  734-487-8431 | Main: 734-487-1055
Email:   jmill251@emich.edu

Notice: This message may be privileged and confidential and protected from
disclosure. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified
that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is
strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error,
please notify me immediately via email, and delete it from your computer.

I'm following up on the following Michigan Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Jan. 7, 2026. You had previously indicated that it would be completed on Jan. 29, 2026. I wanted to check on the status of my request, and to see if there was a new estimated completion date.

communications.subject: Re: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: Beverage Agreements
communications.communication:
Your request is granted in part.  Attached please find existing responsive
records.  Signatures have been redacted from documents pursuant to Section
13(1)(a) of the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, which allows a public
body to refrain from disclosing information that would constitute an
unwarranted invasion of an individual's privacy.

Should you choose to appeal EMU's redactions, you may do one of the
following at your option, pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information
Act (MCL15.235 Sec. 5):

1.  Submit to the University President a written appeal that specifically
states the word “appeal” and identifies the reason(s) for the denial to be
reversed. You may email your appeal to: president@emich.edu; or you may
mail it to Eastern Michigan University   ATTN: President ~ 202 Welch
Hall ~ Ypsilanti,
MI 48197.

2.  Commence an action in the court of claims to compel the University’s
disclosure of the public records within 180 days after the final
determination to deny the request.  If you prevail, you may be awarded
costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. MCL15.240 Sec. 10(7) states: "If the
court determines in an action commenced under this section that the public
body has arbitrarily and capriciously violated this act by refusal or delay
in disclosing or providing copies of a public record, the court shall order
the public body to pay a civil fine of $1,000.00, which shall be deposited
into the general fund of the state treasury. The court shall award, in
addition to any actual or compensatory damages, punitive damages in the
amount of $1,000.00 to the person seeking the right to inspect or receive a
copy of a public record."

For further information on EMU's Procedures & Guidelines regarding FOIA,
please visit our website at http://www.emich.edu/legalaffairs/foia.php.

Thank you,

[image: Jordan Signature.PNG]
*Jordan D. Miller* | Assistant General Counsel
*Eastern Michigan University*
Legal Affairs
11 Welch Hall | Ypsilanti, MI 48197
Direct:  734-487-8431 | Main: 734-487-1055
Email:   jmill251@emich.edu

Notice: This message may be privileged and confidential and protected from
disclosure. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified
that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is
strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error,
please notify me immediately via email, and delete it from your computer.

title: Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

• Record retention schedules
• Any other data structures used for the management of records: digital, paper, and otherwise

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Silvia Canelón

files.title: PA Right to Know Request  Form
files.source: MuckRock

communications.subject: Records - Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)
communications.communication:
THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA      Re: Records - Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)    Your receipt number is: 35596  Dear 199612-91953015@requests. muckrock. com, 

   

 Thank you for your correspondence.  This is an automatic email confirming that your correspondence has been entered into our case management system for processing and response. If you have an additional request you wish to file, or if you wish to make a change to a pending request, please email it directly to righttoknowlaw@.phila.gov.     Did you know that the City already releases a lot of information and open data online?  You might be able to find the answer to your inquiry right now!   

   

 

Here are some common types of requests we receive and where to find this information online right now:  

 

 Search for a property's L&I related permits, licenses, violations, and appeals with the L&I property history tool.  

 

 Search for a property's Real Estate Tax Balance with the Revenue Department's tax real estate lookup tool.  

 

 Find all of the City of Philadelphia's open data sets, including City employee salary data, on Open Data Philly, the Philadelphia region's open data portal.  

 

 Search information about professional service contracts online at eContract Philly.  

 

 Search information about procurement contracts online with PHL Contracts.  

 

 Search City legislation and related hearings online with Legistar.  

 

 Obtain financial disclosure forms from the Department of Records.  

 

 

   If you seek a police incident report, you can obtain the proper form from the Department of Records.  Please note that police incident reports cost $25.      If you seek audio, visual, or bodycam records from the Philadelphia Police Department, you will need to make a request following the instructions in 42 Pa.C.S.A. Sec. 67A03 at https://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/legis/LI/consCheck.cfm?txtType=HTM&ttl=42&div=0&chpt=67A. Such requests must be made in-person or via 

certified mail following the instructions in 42 Pa.C.S.A. §  67A(3) (aka

 Act 22). Such requests are not processed under the RTKL. See 42 Pa.C.S.A. § 67A(2)(a); 65 P.S. §§ 67.305, 67.3101.1. You may use this form to make a request under Act 22. Requests under Act 22  should be addressed to: Lieutenant Barry Jacobs, Philadelphia Police Department, Open Records/Right to Know Section, Philadelphia Public Services Building, 400 N. Broad St., 4W-72, Philadelphia, PA 19130. Such requests are not processed under the Right-to-Know Law.       Use the forms on this page to request copies of various public safety from the Department of Records, such as:   

 Traffic Accident Reports (aka "crash report" - also available through https://public-safety-reports.phila.gov/)  A records check or letter of good conduct from the Philadelphia Police Department  Fire Reports  Emergency Medical Services Reports       The City of Philadelphia does not process Right-to-Know requests for the organizations listed below.  If you want to submit a request to one of these entities, please click the links below to be directed to their Open Records Policies:   

 

Philadelphia Parking Authority  

 

 

School District of Philadelphia  

 

 

City of Philadelphia District Attorney’s Office  

 

 

Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority  

 

 

First Judicial District (Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas)  

 

 

   If one of these sources has solved your inquiry, please let us know!  Otherwise, thank you for your patience, and we will be in touch soon.   Sincerely,   The City of Philadelphia  Please Note: To help make sure that future emails from us don't end up in your spam or junk folder, please add this email address to your safe sender list.

communications.subject: Re: Records - Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)
communications.communication: CITY OF PHILADELPHIA  LAW DEPARTMENT One Parkway Building 1515 Arch Street Philadelphia, PA 19102  Renee Garcia  City Solicitor   BY EMAIL: 199612-91953015@requests.muckrock.com Re: Records - Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia) Request #: 35596  Dear 199612-91953015@requests. muckrock. com:  Thank you for writing to the City of Philadelphia (City) with your request for information. This correspondence serves as an acknowledgement and receipt of your request as well as notice of the City’s Open Records Policy pursuant to the Right-to-Know Law.  Written requests for records to state and local agencies in Pennsylvania are generally governed by the Commonwealth’s Right-to-Know Law (RTKL), 65 P.S. §§ 67.101-67.3104. In accordance with the RTKL, the City has promulgated an Open Records Policy, which requires the standard statewide Right-to-Know Form be used for the submission of written requests pursuant to the RTKL. See 65 P.S. § 67.504(a); Dekok v. Lancaster County, AP 2010-1197, 2011 PA O.O.R.D. LEXIS 25 at *5 and n.1 (Pa. O.O.R. Jan. 17, 2011) (holding that in accordance with the RTKL, an agency may adopt a policy requiring the use of the standard statewide form established by the Office of Open Records in order to file a RTK Request); accord Pa. Gaming Control Bd. v. Office of Open Records, 48 A.3d 503 (Pa. Cmmw. 2012). As your request was not submitted on or with the standard statewide form, the City does not consider your request to be a Right-to-Know Request pursuant to the RTKL and will process it as an informal request.  You do not have to resubmit your request for the City to respond unless you are specifically informed otherwise. The City reserves the right to require a formal RTK Request be submitted pursuant to the RTKL before releasing records. The City is continuing to process the request you have submitted as an informal request outside the RTKL and will be in touch with you further to respond to your request.  However, if you would like to file a RTK Request, please submit your request on or with the standard statewide Right-to-Know Form and email your request to righttoknowlaw@phila.gov – please do not reply to this email. Please include this notice with your RTK Request. Please note that if you resubmit your request as a written request pursuant to the RTKL, the City will deem your informal request to have been withdrawn.   The City’s Open Records Policy can be found here:   https://www.phila.gov/open-records-policy/   The statewide form appears at the end of the City’s Open Records Policy. If you require a hard copy of the form and/or policy, please let me know and one will be provided.  The City reserves the right to assert any and all grounds of denial in its final response to your request.  Respectfully,  Margot B. Smith    Chief Deputy City Solicitor    Right to Know Unit  City of Philadelphia Law Department    Tracking #: Com 35596 Request Summary: Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records: • Record retention schedules • Any other data structures used for the management of records: digital, paper, and otherwise Original Request:

communications.communication:
Re: Records - Records retention schedule (City Of Philadelphia)  Request #: 35596     Dear Muckrock.com:      Thank you for writing to the City of Philadelphia (City) with your request pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right-To-Know Law (RTKL), 65 P.S. § 67.101 et seq. On Dec 15, 2025, the City received your request for:      • Record retention schedules • Any other data structures used for the management of records: digital, paper, and otherwise      On Dec 22, 2025, the City asserted its right to a 30 calendar day extension to respond to your request. This correspondence constitutes the final response to your request by the City Law Department on behalf of its client, the City of Philadelphia. See Philadelphia Home Rule Charter, § 4-400.     Your request is granted and the City's record retention schedules can be found here: https://phila.city/display/records/Records+Retention+Schedules.     Sincerely,     Edward H.V. Skipton III    Deputy City Solicitor/Right to Know Unit  City of Philadelphia Law Department    1515 Arch Street, 15th floor     Philadelphia, PA 19102    (215) 683-2961  Edward.Skipton@phila.gov  www.phila.gov/law            

                           

                            On

                            Tue, Jan 6 at  1:00 AM

                            ,  City of Philadelphia Right to Know <righttoknow@phila.gov>  wrote:

                             THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA     Dear 199612-91953015@requests. muckrock. com,     Thank you for your correspondence. This is an automatic response to let you know that the City will process your request and respond further within five business days of its receipt by an Open Records Officer. Please note that requests received after 4:30 PM are deemed received the next business day.

title: Untitled

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Untitled
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide any documents responsive to request #EPA-R2-2016-008883, received on July 27, 2016.

The subject of the initial request is copied below:

PLEASE SEE ATTACHED LETTER. We respectfully request all materials related to the investigation of any equipment, buildings, sites, and/or locations in Bronx County, New York, in connection with any/all Legionnaires’ Disease outbreak(s), from January 1, 2014 to the present, including, but not limited to, all documents, records, correspondence, testing, sampling data, epidemiological data, research, laboratory results, reports, complaints, studies, photographs, memoranda, notices, warnings, fines, violations, citations, abatements of any cited conditions, inspection records, safety logs, inspections logs and reports, and witness statements including, but not limited to, all of the aforementioned materials related to the following: 1. South Bronx Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak; 2. East Bronx Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak; 3. Morris Park Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak; 4. Opera House Hotel, at 436 East 149th Street, Bronx, New York 100455; 5. Citywide cooling towers investigation; 6. Legionella DNA fingerprinting and results, pulse field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) testing, sequenced based typing (SBT), and whole genome sequencing (WGs) of environmental samples and human isolates; 7. Any patient reporting of Legionnaires’ Disease and/or related illness; 8. Any testing performed at the New York Public Health Laboratory and New York Wadsworth Center Laboratory;

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Justine Streichenberger-Nicolas

title: Seaside - Hilby at Fremont

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Seaside - Hilby at Fremont
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am stating the purpose of this request so that you may assist me as required by California Government Code (“Gov”) § 7922.600(a)(1). The purpose of this California Public Records Act request is to determine the existence or non-existence of a specific record. 

Please note that I am not requesting the record itself, only confirmation of its existence or non-existence. Thus, Civil Code § 1798.90.55, law enforcement exemptions, the public interest exemption or any other laws or exemptions do not apply to, and are not relevant to, this request. 

Please confirm the existence or non-existence of the following Flock Safety ALPR footage record:

License Plate: 9SYY133
Date: January 20, 2026
Time Frame: 11:10 AM - 11:15 AM
Camera Location: Hilby at Fremont
Camera Lat/long: 36.60253000048354, -121.84855266543457

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Moore

title: Seaside - Hilby at Mescal

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Seaside - Hilby at Mescal
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am stating the purpose of this request so that you may assist me as required by California Government Code (“Gov”) § 7922.600(a)(1). The purpose of this California Public Records Act request is to determine the existence or non-existence of a specific record. 

Please note that I am not requesting the record itself, only confirmation of its existence or non-existence. Thus, Civil Code § 1798.90.55, law enforcement exemptions, the public interest exemption or any other laws or exemptions do not apply to, and are not relevant to, this request. 

Please confirm the existence or non-existence of the following Flock Safety ALPR footage record:

License Plate: 9SYY133
Date: January 20, 2026
Time Frame: 11:15 AM - 11:20 AM
Camera Location: Hilby at Mescal
Camera Lat/long: 36.60210107146968, -121.82709446938085

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Moore

title: IHSC Stewart 911 SENs/SIRs

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: IHSC Stewart 911 SENs/SIRs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e) and declare the following statements in support thereof to be true and correct under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746: 

1. The Stewart Detention Center has the highest number of deaths in ICE custody of any facility in the ICE detention since FY17. 
2. Stewart is currently one of the most populated sites of detention in the ICE system. 
3. Calls to 911 in 2025 from Stewart have exceeded their numbers for any period over the past five years. 
4. Audio recordings of Stewart 911 calls reflect instances in which EMS units were unavailable to treat significant illnesses or injuries as a result of previous calls from the facility.
5. Lack of access to timely emergency medical care threatens the health safety of people in Stewart and the surrounding community. 
6. ICE Mortality Reviewers have attributed lack of timely access to emergency medical care to a significant number of deaths in ICE custody. 
7. The records requested will shed light on whether, and to what extent, ICE is aware of the challenges posed and consequences created by its use of detention in high numbers at the Stewart facility. 
8. DHS-OIG, ICE OPR, IHSC, ICE ODO, Congress, and the General Accountability Office have all previously cited CoreCivic, ICE's Atlanta Field Office, and Stewart for violations of ICE's standards and contracts. 
9. I am a member of the media primarily engaged in information dissemination through edited publications, and have previously been granted expedited processing by federal FOIA offices on this basis. 
10. These records are needed on an expedited basis to fill out the federal side of a piece for which I have received journalism grant funding and which will be published no later than October.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: Your verification code
communications.communication: Your confirmation code is 505533

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
09/04/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/27/2025, and to your request for expedited treatment. Your request was received in this office on 8/27/2025. Specifically, you requested records pertaining to ll Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

Your request for expedited treatment is hereby denied. 

Under the DHS FOIA regulations, expedited processing of a FOIA request is warranted if the request involves “circumstances in which the lack of expedited treatment could reasonably be expected to pose an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(i), or “an urgency to inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity, if made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(l)(ii).  Requesters seeking expedited processing must submit a statement explaining in detail the basis for the request, and that statement must be certified by the requester to be true and correct.  6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(3). 

Your request for expedited processing is denied because you do not qualify for either category under 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1).  You failed to demonstrate a particular urgency to inform the public about the government activity involved in the request beyond the public’s right to know about government activity generally.  Your letter was conclusory in nature and did not present any facts to justify a grant of expedited processing under the applicable standards. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10- day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you care to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

If you deem the decision to deny expedited treatment of your request an adverse determination, you have the right to appeal.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(e)(2). You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street,, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

ICE has queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact the FOIA office or Daniel Edgington, FOIA Public Liaison at 500 12th St. SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009 or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned tracking number 2025-ICFO-57001. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
Andrew Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-57001 
 
Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/27/2025.  You have requested records pertaining to Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Stewart Detention Center for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through August 26, 2025. 

ICE has considered your request under both the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a.  Information about an individual that is maintained in a Privacy Act system of records may be accessed by that individual unless the agency has exempted the system of records from the access provisions of the Privacy Act. 

ICE has conducted a search of the ICE Office of Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) for records responsive to your request and no records responsive to your request were found. 

For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA.  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(c) (2006 & Supp. IV (2010).  This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA.  This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. 

While an adequate search was conducted, you have the right to appeal this determination that no records exist within the above mentioned ICE office(s).  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of the original response letter, within 90 days of the date of the letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8.  You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009 and refer to your tracking number. Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication: I appeal the adequacy of the agency's search and seek expedited processing of this appeal. There is an urgent need to inform the public about the underlying causes of the hundreds of calls Stewart generated this period--calls which are rising in volume and severity. I am actively reporting on these issues and require these ICE records (or final confirmation they do not exist) to provide a full picture of ICE's response. See, e.g., https://theintercept.com/2025/12/12/stewart-911-calls-ice-ambulance-emergency/. If, in fact, the agency has no responsive records, please provide final confirmation of this so I can officially report it.

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2026-ICAP-00094, 2025-ICFO-57001
communications.communication:
12/31/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR192063 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2026-ICAP-00094 

Dear Requester: 

The Department of Homeland Security has received your letter appealing the adverse determination of your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy Act (FOIA/PA) request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Your appeal, dated 12/12/2025, was received on 12/30/2025. 

The Government Information Law Division acknowledges your appeal request of and is assigning it number 2026-ICAP-00094 for tracking purposes.  Please reference this number in any future communications about your appeal. 

A high number of FOIA/PA requests have been received by the Department.  Accordingly, we have adopted the court-sanctioned practice of generally handling backlogged appeals on a first-in, first-out basis.   While we will make every effort to process your appeal on a timely basis, there may be some delay in resolving this matter.  Should you have any questions concerning the processing of your appeal, please contact Daniel Edgington ICE FOIA Office/Public Liaison at (866) 633-1182 or at 500 12th St., SW Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 
 
Sara Jazayeri 
Chief 
Government Information Law Division 
ICE Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security

title: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

December 23, 2025

Clerk of Superior Court
Attn: Archives/Records
556 North McDonough Street 
Decatur GA, 30030

Re: Georgia Open Records Act Request – Case No. 25CV7033

Dear Open Records Officer,

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, OCGA § 50-18-70 et seq., and in accordance with Uniform Superior Court Rule 21, which governs the disclosure of records related to judicial proceedings, I respectfully request access to the following public administrative records concerning Case No. 25CV7033 in DeKalb County Superior Court::

1. Deputy Clerk Identities
Names of all deputy clerks who processed, reviewed, or rejected the filings listed in Exhibit A of the Plaintiff’s Motion for Judicial Review.

2. Digital and Administrative Records
For each filing listed in Exhibit A, I request:
Any internal audit logs, access logs, activity histories, or system-generated records maintained by the Clerk’s Office within any electronic case management, e-filing, or document management system used to receive, review, process, or store the filings, identifying all users who accessed or took administrative action on those filings.

Metadata associated with filings, including timestamps, user actions, and internal notes.

Internal clerk review annotations, comments, or correspondence associated with each filing.

Any administrative records generated in the course of processing these filings.

Copies of all filings and docket entries to ensure a complete and accurate record, including updates or amendments.

3. Administrative Policies and Training Materials
Written policies, procedures, or training materials regarding the processing, review, and handling of filings in the Superior Court Civil Division.

This request is limited to administrative records and public documentation; it does not seek confidential judicial deliberations or privileged communications. If any portion of a responsive record is claimed to be exempt from disclosure, please produce the non-exempt portions with redactions as permitted by law and identify the specific statutory basis for each redaction or withholding, as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d).”

The purpose of this request is to identify the appropriate individuals responsible for processing these filings and to obtain a complete administrative and digital record(s). This request applies to any electronic system or database used by the Clerk’s Office to receive, process, review, manage, or store filings for this case, regardless of vendor or system name.

If any fees are associated with producing these records, please notify me prior to processing. I request that the records be provided in electronic format, if available.
Thank you for your attention to this request. 

Sincerely,
/s/ Charles Stanley DeLozier Jr.,  pro se

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Charles Stanley DeLozier Jr.

title: Weymouth Wednesdays

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Weymouth Wednesdays
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Subject: FOIA Request for Information Regarding Traffic Enforcement Policies

 I am writing to request information under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) related to the traffic enforcement policies of Weymouth Police Department.  Specifically, I seek documentation regarding the recent directive that instructs officers and command staff to conduct traffic enforcement exclusively on Wednesdays.

To assist in the processing of this request, please provide:

1. Any memos, emails, or internal communications from agency leadership discussing or promoting the strategy to issue tickets solely on Wednesdays.

2. Statistical data or reports that outline traffic enforcement activities, including the number of tickets issued on Wednesdays compared to other days of the week.

3. Any relevant guidelines or policies that mandate or suggest certain days for traffic enforcement over others.

4. Information on the objectives behind this strategy and whether any analysis was conducted before its implementation.

I propose a fee waiver for this request based on the public interest in transparency around law enforcement practices. This information is crucial for understanding how these policies may impact public safety and the fair application of traffic laws.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

TransparentPolicing2026

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Forsyth County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

communications.subject: Forsyth County Sheriff's Office - Record Request 2026-871
communications.communication:
Dear Requester, 
  
 Thank you for submitting a request for records.

Your request security key is 67930485.
Your request reference number is Request Number: 2026-871.

Please have this security key and reference number available when communicating with our staff regarding your request. 
  
 Open Records Requests: 
  
 The Open Records Unit will provide information relating to the request, as permissible and applicable by law, within 3 business days after it has been received. If production of requested documents is not possible within that timeframe, the Open Records Unit will issue correspondence with an explanation. If your request is denied in whole or in part, the legal basis for denial will be cited in the response. If production of the requested documents exceeds a fee above $25.00, the requester will be contacted with a pre-retrieval cost estimate prior to fulfilling the request. 
  
 Associated Charges: 
  
 The first 15 minutes of any response are provided at no cost.  Staff time to comply with request will be billed as follows: 
  
 Balance of first hour $15.41 
 Additional hours $20.54 each 
  
 Production Fees: 
  
 Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)(1)...the charge for the search, retrieval, or redaction of records shall not exceed the prorated hourly salary of the lowest paid full-time employee who, in the reasonable discretion of the custodian of the records, has the necessary skill and training to perform the request; provided, however, that no charge shall be made for the first quarter hour. Other fees: 
 Copies 10¢ per letter or legal-size page 
 Copies non-standard size actual cost 
 Off-site retrieval actual cost (off site retrieval could take up to 10 days) 
 Electronic media actual cost 
 Other specialized records actual cost - as provided by law. 
 Certified copies - as provided by law. 
  
 Once your response is completed, you will receive directions to pay any charges to release the records.  
  
  *Forsyth County residents whose name appear on the records will receive one copy of their accident or incident report at no cost.* 
  
 In accordance with OCGA 50-18-72 Records requests and responses may be subject to disclosure under the State Open Records Act. 
  
 Thank you, 
  
 Forsyth County Sheriff's Office
100 East Courthouse Square
Cumming, GA 30040
770-781-2222

Any and all documents related to State Case # 13-1991-CF-030032-B000-XX against Latrice Jones (F-91-030032-B). 

All pre-trial documents including discovery materials including evidence (photos, witness statements), confessions/oral or written plea agreement deals (from other co-defendants), statements/depositions (both written and transcribed)  from all potential witnesses or experts (i.e, Dr. Gary Schwarz, David Bosworth,  Rebecca Mendoza, Tyrone Coates, Louis Coates) , arrest warrants, police reports, depositions and/or reports). 

Any written or oral/transcribed statements by Latrice Jones (i.e., alleged waivers of defendants' presence in court, written/transcribed plea agreements). This should include all signed statements by Latrice Jones. 

Some of the evidence cited above may be found in the files of co-defendants (Tyrone Coates: F-91-030032-A |State Case # 13-1991-CF-030032-A000-XX or Rebecca Mendoza: F-91-030032-C |State Case Number 13-1991-CF-030032-C000-XX)

Most of these documents should fall between July 1991 through June 1993. There may be some appeals from 1993 until 2018 which I would also be interested in requesting.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

title: Police Information Sharing Policies with Immigration Authorities

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Police Information Sharing Policies with Immigration Authorities
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

1. All departmental or municipal policies regarding communication and information sharing between departmental officers or employees and federal agents/agencies within the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) or the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), including but not limited to the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The records request includes, but is not limited to, policies regarding: 

A. Fingerprint and other data sharing, 

B. ICE detainer requests,   

C. Compliance with federal immigration enforcement efforts, including guidance or policies around when communication with ICE officers is allowed, and 

D. Communicating with federal immigration enforcement officers. 

This request covers any policies that are currently in effect or that have been in effect at any point on or after January 20, 2025. 

2. The three most recent communications (e.g., emails, text messages, call logs or transcripts, or otherwise) between a departmental officer or employee and a federal DHS or ICE employee. In addition, I request all records related to these communications, including, but not limited to, any records indicating that the department was made aware of the communications, discussions of their content or implications, evaluations them for compliance with departmental or other city policies, identification or acknowledgement of any potential policy violations, and any internal responses, disciplinary actions, or follow-up measures resulting from these communications. 

3. All records relating to incidents, if any, from January 20, 2025, to the day this request is responded to, in which an individual was taken from the department’s custody directly into ICE custody. For each incident, the records request includes, but is not limited to, booking and transfer records, communications with ICE or other federal agencies, internal documentation or discussion of the transfer, and internal notes, memos, or documentation referencing communication with DHS or ICE.

For each request, I am not seeking identifying information, and I will accept anonymized or redacted data as necessary to protect identities. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Joshua Dankoff 

Joshuadankoff@cfjj.org  

Director of Strategic Initiatives 

Citizens for Juvenile Justice  

(submitted via MuckRock platform)

title: ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSE RECORDS Title: Administrative Response Records - Wallingford Public Schools

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSE RECORDS Title: Administrative Response Records - Wallingford Public Schools
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. § 1-200 et seq.), I respectfully request access to the following public records:

PRIMARY RECORDS REQUESTED:
- All communications and documentation related to Policy 1312 grievance procedures from July 1, 2025 to present
- All communications between Principal Robert Arceiro and Superintendent Danielle Bellizzi regarding the Conrad family from January 1, 2023 to present
- All documentation of any conflict of interest determinations, discussions, or evaluations involving school employees and external parties from January 1, 2024 to present
- Training records for all staff regarding professional boundaries, workplace conduct policies, and custody dispute protocols

COMPREHENSIVE DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS:
This request includes, but is not limited to:
- All responsive records regardless of format (paper, electronic, audio, video, social media, messaging apps)
- Records stored on personal devices if used for official business
- Records in possession of contractors, consultants, or third parties acting on behalf of the agency
- Draft documents, notes, calendars, and informal communications
- Records that have been deleted but remain recoverable
- Metadata and audit logs associated with electronic records

SEARCH REQUIREMENTS:
- Search all relevant custodians, not just those specifically named
- Search all email accounts, shared drives, and backup systems
- Include records of employees no longer with the agency
- Search alternative spellings, nicknames, and partial names

PRODUCTION STANDARDS:
- Provide records in native electronic format when possible
- Do not convert searchable documents to non-searchable formats
- Preserve all metadata including timestamps and sender/recipient information
- Provide a privilege log for any claimed exemptions

If any responsive records have been destroyed, please provide:
- Documentation of the destruction
- Reason for destruction
- Date of destruction
- Authority for destruction

If you claim any exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, please:
- Identify the specific statutory exemption
- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Bastrop County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

communications.communication:
Hello,

It looks like this request was going to an old email address, so we've redirected the request to this contact.

---

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. § 1-200 et seq.), I respectfully request access to the following public records:

PRIMARY RECORDS REQUESTED:
- All policies and procedures regarding employee conduct during custody disputes or family court matters
- Documentation of FERPA compliance training for staff, including attendance records and training materials
- Records showing how complaints to the Superintendent's office are processed, tracked, and resolved from January 1, 2024 to present
- Any legal consultations, advice, or opinions received regarding employee conflicts of interest from January 1, 2024 to present

COMPREHENSIVE DISCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS:
This request includes, but is not limited to:
- All responsive records regardless of format (paper, electronic, audio, video, social media, messaging apps)
- Records stored on personal devices if used for official business
- Records in possession of contractors, consultants, or third parties acting on behalf of the agency
- Draft documents, notes, calendars, and informal communications
- Records that have been deleted but remain recoverable
- Metadata and audit logs associated with electronic records

SEARCH REQUIREMENTS:
- Search all relevant custodians, not just those specifically named
- Search all email accounts, shared drives, and backup systems
- Include records of employees no longer with the agency
- Search alternative spellings, nicknames, and partial names

PRODUCTION STANDARDS:
- Provide records in native electronic format when possible
- Do not convert searchable documents to non-searchable formats
- Preserve all metadata including timestamps and sender/recipient information
- Provide a privilege log for any claimed exemptions

If any responsive records have been destroyed, please provide:
- Documentation of the destruction
- Reason for destruction
- Date of destruction
- Authority for destruction

If you claim any exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, please:
- Identify the specific statutory exemption
- Explain how the exemption applies to each document
- Provide redacted copies where partial disclosure is possible
- Consider whether public interest outweighs any claimed exemption

This request seeks records that serve the public interest in government transparency and accountability. Please construe all exemptions narrowly and err on the side of disclosure.

Please preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request to prevent spoliation.

As these records serve significant public interest, please waive all fees. If fees cannot be waived, please provide detailed cost estimate before proceeding.

Thank you for your assistance.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

john Conrad

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am in receipt of your departments FOI request for Food Service License Renewals for 2025-2026. I find it very concerning that several Class IV Establishments have yet to be renewed over 6 months after prior permit expired. One of  which is a daycare that services a vulnerable population. 
Public Health Code Regulations have an inspection interval requirement.

Please furnish copies of DPH required inspections for the following Establishments for calendar years 2024, 2025, and 2026 until the receipt of this request.

FSE-22-151	5/14/2025 18:34	Active	Sushi Do Danbury Hospital	                        Class IV
FSE-22-5	6/11/2025 14:37	Active	Cedar Gables Preschool & Childcare	Class IV
FSE-23-33	6/19/2025 22:51	Active	Bambu	                                                                Class IV

Please provide explanation if no inspections have been conducted.
